org_name: Mercy Health - Springfield Regional Medical Center

forms.document_type: Patient access request form (wrong organization — mercy.net / Missouri Mercy, not Bon Secours Mercy Health)
ROI authorization form (Youngstown region — wrong facility)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients are directed to an eRequest portal (Swellbox/Datavant) or MyChart, with a downloadable generic HIPAA authorization form as fallback; no dedicated patient access form exists.

red_flags: Photo ID required at time of request — ambiguous for remote submissions and not required by HIPAA for patient access
Entire record defaults to only two years of information unless patient specifies otherwise, potentially limiting HIPAA Right of Access
Primary linked form on website is an image-only scan; superior text-based Springfield version is hidden and undiscoverable through normal navigation
bright_spots: Electronic format (PDF/CD) is the default when not specified — progressive stance favoring digital delivery
Personal use is the default purpose — patients need not justify why they want their own records
Explicit citation of 45 CFR § 164.524 (HIPAA Right of Access) in form legal text
MyChart listed as a delivery method alongside traditional options
eRequest portal via Swellbox/Datavant provides a fully digital request pathway

findability.rationale: Level 3: The medical records page is findable via standard navigation, but the best PDF form for Springfield is hidden behind URL guessing, and the linked system-wide form is an unusable image-only scan; the eRequest portal partially compensates.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: The eRequest/Swellbox portal provides a mostly digital workflow, and fax/email submission is available; however the PDF forms have zero fillable fields, creating a gap when patients choose the paper pathway.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Form-4 is logically organized on one page with clear record-type checkboxes, but the legal section is dense legalese and the 'entire record' two-year default is a content design failure that could mislead patients.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: The PDF form is a generic 'Authorization for Release' where patients must locate the 'Self' checkbox and navigate third-party-oriented framing; patient access is possible but not the form's primary design intent.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Photo ID requirement and two-year default for 'entire record' go beyond what HIPAA requires for patient access; fee disclosure is vague with no cost-based fee distinction; however, no notarization or in-person-only barriers exist.

overall.summary: Mercy Health Springfield provides multiple request channels including a digital portal, but its PDF forms are generic authorizations with no fillable fields, the linked version is an image-only scan, and the Springfield-specific text form is hidden — resulting in a fragmented experience that works for portal-savvy patients but creates unnecessary friction for those seeking a traditional form.
